title: 104_hr4110
content: The "Children Health Insurance Act of 1996" requires health insurance availability for children through amendments to the Internal Revenue Code, including excise tax for failure to provide coverage and defining access to coverage. A tax is imposed on group health plans and insurers for failing to meet coverage requirements. The tax amount is 25 percent of premiums received for the plan year. A tax of 25 percent of premiums paid is imposed on insurers offering individual health insurance coverage for any failure with respect to coverage requirements. No tax is imposed if the failure is not discovered through reasonable diligence. Tax of 25% on premiums for insurers offering individual health insurance coverage for failures, waived if corrected within 30 days due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. The Secretary may waive part or all of the tax for failures due to reasonable cause, not willful neglect. The tax does not apply to governmental or church plans. The responsible party for the tax depends on the type of plan or insurer. "SEC. 9902. REQUIREMENT OF ACCESS TO COVERAGE." Group health plans must offer qualifying coverage for qualifying young dependents of participants or beneficiaries. The offer must be made when a person first becomes a qualifying young dependent and at least annually thereafter. Insurers in the individual market must offer qualifying coverage for individuals under 21 years of age who are U.S. citizens or nationals. The term 'qualifying coverage' refers to health care benefits that include Medicare benefits without limitations based on pre-existing conditions or waiting periods. Coinsurance for part B services should not exceed $10 or 10% of the recognized payment amount. Payment for newborn and well-baby care, pediatrician services for high-risk deliveries, routine well-child care including office visits, immunizations, laboratory tests, and preventive dental care, without deductibles, coinsurance, or copayments. The Secretary, in consultation with the American Academy of Pediatrics, will establish a periodicity schedule for preventive dental care for health children. Managed care is permitted for providing benefits to qualifying young dependents under 21 years of age in the United States. To qualify for benefits, an individual must be 21 years old, a U.S. citizen or national (or a permanent resident), and a dependent as defined in section 152. "SEC. 9903. DEFINITIONS." "In this chapter, the term 'group health plan' is defined as per section 5000(b)(1), excluding plans with medical benefits limited to coverage in paragraph (2)(B). 'Health insurance coverage' refers to medical care benefits under various policies or contracts, excluding certain exceptions." The term 'group health plan' is defined in this chapter, excluding plans with limited medical benefits. 'Health insurance coverage' refers to medical care benefits under policies or contracts, with exceptions for specific types of coverage. The curr_chunk lists various types of insurance coverage, including liability insurance, workers' compensation, automobile medical-payment insurance, coverage for specified diseases, hospital indemnity insurance, short-term limited duration insurance, and other comparable coverage. The curr_chunk defines a health maintenance organization as a federally qualified organization, one recognized under State law, or a similar organization regulated for solvency under State law. It must be subject to State insurance regulations. The curr_chunk provides definitions related to health insurance, including terms like insurer, individual market, and incorporation of certain definitions. These definitions are important for understanding the regulations and scope of health insurance coverage. The curr_chunk incorporates definitions of 'beneficiary' and 'participant' from the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. This amendment is reflected in the table of contents for the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Subtitle L. Health Insurance Availability for Children. The requirement of section 9902 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be effective on January 1, 1998, applying to coverage offered on or after that date. A refundable tax credit for the purchase of health coverage for children is introduced in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. Tax liability is defined as the excess of the tax imposed for the year, reduced by other credits. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year. The credit is applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. Social security taxes for the taxable year are calculated by subtracting the credit allowed under section 32. The tax credit allows individuals to claim 80% of qualified health premiums paid in the taxable year, applied against tax liability at a rate of $0.50 for each $1 of tax liability. Social security taxes do not include taxes eligible for a special refund under section 6413(c) or amounts paid under an agreement with American employers under section 3121(l). Agreements with American employers for foreign affiliates are treated as taxes under this section. Definitions for terms like qualified health premium, health coverage, and qualifying young dependent are provided. Section 35 in the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 is amended. The amendments in sections 35 and 36 relate to the purchase of health coverage for children and overpayments of tax, respectively. These changes will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1997.
